_readme: This file is automatically generated by our phpDocGen.php and is
a part of our auto-documentation process. If you see a mistake,
please edit the documentation in the respective function files.

methods.name: append
methods.summary: Append an item to array.
methods.description:
Usage

__::append([1, 2, 3], 4);

Result

[1, 2, 3, 4]

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: The new item or value to append

methods.name: chunk
methods.summary: Creates an array of elements split into groups the length of $size.
methods.description:
If array can't be split evenly, the final chunk will be the remaining elements. When $preserveKeys is set to TRUE, keys will be preserved. Default is FALSE, which will reindex the chunk numerically.

Usage

__::chunk([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 3);

Result

[[1, 2, 3], [4, 5]]

arguments.name: preserveKeys
arguments.description: Whether or not to preserve index keys

exceptions.message: when an non-array or non-traversable object is given for $iterable.
when an `\IteratorAggregate` is given and `getIterator()` throws an exception.

return.description: When given a \Traversable object for $iterable, a generator will be returned. Otherwise, an array will be returned.

methods.name: compact
methods.summary: Creates an array with all falsey values removed.
methods.description:
The following values are considered falsey:

  • false
  • null
  • 0
  • ""
  • undefined
  • NaN

Usage

__::compact([0, 1, false, 2, '', 3]);

Result

[1, 2, 3]

methods.name: drop
methods.summary: Creates a slice of array with n elements dropped from the beginning.
methods.description:
Usage

__::drop([0, 1, 3, 5], 2);

Result

[3, 5]

arguments.name: input
arguments.description: The array or iterable to query.

arguments.name: number
arguments.description: The number of elements to drop.

methods.name: flatten
methods.summary: Flattens a multidimensional array or iterable.
methods.description:
If $shallow is set to TRUE, the array will only be flattened a single level.

Usage

__::flatten([1, 2, [3, [4]]], false);

Result

[1, 2, 3, 4]

methods.name: patch
methods.summary: Patches array by xpath.
methods.description:
Usage

__::patch(

    [

        'addr' => [

            'country' => 'US',

            'zip' => 12345

        ]

    ],

    [

        '/addr/country' => 'CA',

        '/addr/zip' => 54321

    ]

);

Result

['addr' => ['country' => 'CA', 'zip' => 54321]]

methods.name: prepend
methods.summary: Prepend item or value to an array.
methods.description:
Usage

__::prepend([1, 2, 3], 4);

Result

[4, 1, 2, 3]

methods.name: randomize
methods.summary: Shuffle an array ensuring no item remains in the same position.
methods.description:
Usage

__::randomize([1, 2, 3]);

Result

[2, 3, 1]

methods.name: range
methods.summary: Generate range of values based on start, end, and step.
methods.description:
Usage

__::range(1, 10, 2);

Result

[1, 3, 5, 7, 9]

methods.name: repeat
methods.summary: Generate array of repeated values.
methods.description:
Usage

__::repeat('foo', 3);

Result

['foo', 'foo', 'foo']

arguments.name: times
arguments.description: How many times has to be repeated.

return.description: Returns a new array of filled values.

methods.name: assign
methods.summary: Combines and merge collections provided with each others.
methods.description:
If the collections have common keys, then the last passed keys override the previous. If numerical indexes are passed, then last passed indexes override the previous.

For a recursive merge, see __::merge().

Usage

__::assign(

    [

        'color' => [

            'favorite' => 'red',

            5

        ],

        3

    ],

    [

        10,

        'color' => [

            'favorite' => 'green',

            'blue'

        ]

    ]

);

Result

[

    'color' => ['favorite' => 'green', 'blue'],

    10

]

methods.name: concat
methods.summary: Combines and concat collections provided with each others.
methods.description:
If the collections have common keys, then the values are appended in an array. If numerical indexes are passed, then values are appended.

For a recursive merge, see __::merge().

Usage

__::concat(

    ['color' => ['favorite' => 'red', 5], 3],

    [10, 'color' => ['favorite' => 'green', 'blue']]

);

Result

[

    'color' => ['favorite' => ['green'], 5, 'blue'],

    3,

    10

]

return.description: If the first argument given to this function is an \stdClass, an \stdClass will be returned. Otherwise, an array will be returned.

methods.name: concatDeep
methods.summary: Recursively combines and concat collections provided with each others.
methods.description:
If the collections have common keys, then the values are appended in an array. If numerical indexes are passed, then values are appended.

For a non-recursive concat, see __::concat().

Usage

__::concatDeep(

    ['color' => ['favorite' => 'red', 5], 3],

    [10, 'color' => ['favorite' => 'green', 'blue']]

);

Result

[

    'color' => [

        'favorite' => ['red', 'green'],

        5,

        'blue'

    ],

    3,

    10

]

return.description: A concatenated collection. When the first argument given is an \stdClass, then resulting value will be an \stdClass. Otherwise, an array will always be returned.

methods.name: doForEach
methods.summary: Iterate over elements of the collection and invokes iteratee for each element.
methods.description:
The iteratee is invoked with three arguments: (value, index|key, collection). Iteratee functions may exit iteration early by explicitly returning false.

Usage

__::doForEach([1, 2, 3], function ($value, $key, $collection) {

    print_r($value)

});

Result

(Side effect: print 1, 2, 3)

arguments.name: iteratee
arguments.description: The function to call for each value.

methods.name: doForEachRight
methods.summary: Iterate over elements of the collection, from right to left, and invokes iteratee for each element.
methods.description:
The iteratee is invoked with three arguments: (value, index|key, collection). Iteratee functions may exit iteration early by explicitly returning false.

Usage

__::doForEachRight([1, 2, 3], function ($value, $key, $collection) {

    print_r($value);

});

Result

(Side effect: print 3, 2, 1)

arguments.name: iteratee
arguments.description: The function to call for each value.

methods.name: ease
methods.summary: Flattens a complex collection by mapping each ending leafs value to a key consisting of all previous indexes.
methods.description:
Usage

__::ease([

    'foo' => ['bar' => 'ter'],

    'baz' => ['b', 'z']

]);

Result

[

    'foo.bar' => 'ter',

    'baz.0' => 'b',

    'baz.1' => 'z'

]

methods.name: every
methods.summary: Checks if predicate returns truthy for all elements of collection.
methods.description:
Iteration is stopped once predicate returns falsey.

Usage

__::every([1, 3, 4], function ($value, $key, $collection) {

    return is_int($v);

});

Result

true

arguments.name: iteratee
arguments.description: The function to call for each value.

methods.name: filter
methods.summary: Returns the values in the collection that pass the truth test.
methods.description:
When $closure is set to null, this function will automatically remove falsey values. When $closure is given, then values where the closure returns false will be removed.

Usage

$a = [

    ['name' => 'fred',   'age' => 32],

    ['name' => 'maciej', 'age' => 16]

];



__::filter($a, function($n) {

    return $n['age'] > 24;

});

Result

[['name' => 'fred', 'age' => 32]]

exceptions.message: when an non-array or non-traversable object is given for $iterable.

return.description: When given a \Traversable object for $iterable, a generator will be returned. Otherwise, an array will be returned.

methods.name: first
methods.summary: Gets the first element of an array/iterable. Passing n returns the first n elements.
methods.description:
When $count is null, only the first element will be returned.

Usage

__::first([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 2);

Result

[1, 2]

methods.name: get
methods.summary: Get item of an array or object by index, accepting path (nested index).
methods.description:
If $collection is an object that implements the ArrayAccess interface, this function will treat it as an array instead of accessing class properties.

Use a period (.) in $path to go down a level in a multidimensional array.

Usage

__::get(['foo' => ['bar' => 'ter']], 'foo.bar');

Result

'ter'

arguments.name: path
arguments.description:
Array key or object attribute. Use a period
for depicting a new level in a multidimensional
array

arguments.name: default
arguments.description: Default value to return if index not exist

methods.name: getIterator
methods.summary: Get an iterator from an object that supports iterators; including generators.

methods.name: groupBy
methods.summary: Returns an associative array where the keys are values of $key.
methods.description:
Based on Chauncey McAskill's array_group_by() function.

Group by Key Usage

__::groupBy([

        ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Indianapolis', 'object' => 'School bus'],

        ['state' => 'CA', 'city' => 'San Diego', 'object' => 'Light bulb'],

        ['state' => 'CA', 'city' => 'Mountain View', 'object' => 'Space pen'],

    ],

    'state'

);

Result

[

  'IN' => [

     ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Indianapolis', 'object' => 'School bus'],

  ],

  'CA' => [

     ['state' => 'CA', 'city' => 'San Diego', 'object' => 'Light bulb'],

     ['state' => 'CA', 'city' => 'Mountain View', 'object' => 'Space pen'],

  ]

]

Group by Nested Key (Dot Notation)

__::groupBy([

        ['object' => 'School bus', 'metadata' => ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Indianapolis']],

        ['object' => 'Manhole', 'metadata' => ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Indianapolis']],

        ['object' => 'Basketball', 'metadata' => ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Plainfield']],

        ['object' => 'Light bulb', 'metadata' => ['state' => 'CA', 'city' => 'San Diego']],

        ['object' => 'Space pen', 'metadata' => ['state' => 'CA', 'city' => 'Mountain View']],

    ],

    'metadata.state'

);

Result

[

  'IN' => [

    'Indianapolis' => [

      ['object' => 'School bus', 'metadata' => ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Indianapolis']],

      ['object' => 'Manhole', 'metadata' => ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Indianapolis']],

    ],

    'Plainfield' => [

      ['object' => 'Basketball', 'metadata' => ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Plainfield']],

    ],

  ],

  'CA' => [

    'San Diego' => [

      ['object' => 'Light bulb', 'metadata' => ['state' => 'CA', 'city' => 'San Diego']],

    ],

    'Mountain View' => [

      ['object' => 'Space pen', 'metadata' => ['state' => 'CA', 'city' => 'Mountain View']],

    ],

  ],

]

Group by Closure Usage

__::groupBy([

        (object)['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Indianapolis', 'object' => 'School bus'],

        (object)['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Indianapolis', 'object' => 'Manhole'],

        (object)['state' => 'CA', 'city' => 'San Diego', 'object' => 'Light bulb'],

    ],

    function ($value) {

        return $value->city;

    }

);

Result

[

  'Indianapolis' => [

     ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Indianapolis', 'object' => 'School bus'],

     ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Indianapolis', 'object' => 'Manhole'],

  ],

  'San Diego' => [

     ['state' => 'CA', 'city' => 'San Diego', 'object' => 'Light bulb'],

  ]

]

methods.name: has
methods.summary: Return true if $collection contains the requested $key.
methods.description:
In contrast to isset(), __::has() returns true if the key exists but is null.

Array Usage

 __::has(['foo' => ['bar' => 'num'], 'foz' => 'baz'], 'foo.bar');

Result

true

Object Usage

 __::hasKeys((object) ['foo' => 'bar', 'foz' => 'baz'], 'bar');

Result

false

arguments.name: collection
arguments.description: Array or object to search a key for

arguments.name: path
arguments.description: Path to look for. Supports dot notation for traversing multiple levels.

methods.name: hasKeys
methods.summary: Returns true if $input contains all requested $keys. If $strict is true it also checks if $input exclusively contains the given $keys.
methods.description:
Usage

__::hasKeys(['foo' => 'bar', 'foz' => 'baz'], ['foo', 'foz']);

Result

true

arguments.name: keys
arguments.description: collection of keys to look for

methods.name: isEmpty
methods.summary: Check if value is an empty array or object.
methods.description:
We consider any non enumerable as empty.

Usage

__::isEmpty([]);

Result

true

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: The value to check for emptiness.

methods.name: last
methods.summary: Get last item(s) of an array.
methods.description:
Usage

__::last([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 2);

Result

[4, 5]

methods.name: map
methods.summary: Returns an array of values by mapping each in collection through the iteratee.
methods.description:
Usage

__::map([1, 2, 3], function($value, $key, $collection) {

    return $value * 3;

});

Result

[3, 6, 9]

arguments.name: collection
arguments.description: The collection of values to map over.

arguments.name: iteratee
arguments.description: The function to apply on each value.

methods.name: mapKeys
methods.summary: Transforms the keys in a collection by running each key through the iterator.
methods.description:
This function throws an \Exception when the closure doesn't return a valid key that can be used in a PHP array.

Usage

__::mapKeys(['x' => 1], function($key, $value, $collection) {

    return "{$key}_{$value}";

});

Result

['x_1' => 1]

exceptions.message: when closure doesn't return a valid key that can be used in PHP array

methods.name: mapValues
methods.summary: Transforms the values in a collection by running each value through the iterator.
methods.description:
Usage

__::mapValues(['x' => 1], function($value, $key, $collection) {

    return "{$key}_{$value}";

});

Result

['x' => 'x_1']

methods.name: max
methods.summary: Returns the maximum value from the collection.
methods.description:
If passed an iterator, max will return max value returned by the iterator.

Usage

__::max([1, 2, 3]);

Result

3

methods.name: merge
methods.summary: Recursively combines and merge collections provided with each others.
methods.description:
• If the collections have common keys, then the last passed keys override the previous.
  • If numerical indexes are passed, then last passed indexes override the previous.

For a non-recursive merge, see __::assign().

Usage

__::merge(

    ['color' => ['favorite' => 'red', 'model' => 3, 5], 3],

    [10, 'color' => ['favorite' => 'green', 'blue']]

);

Result

['color' => ['favorite' => 'green', 'model' => 3, 'blue'], 10]

methods.name: min
methods.summary: Returns the minimum value from the collection. If passed an iterator, min will return min value returned by the iterator.
methods.description:
Usage

__::min([1, 2, 3]);

Result

1

methods.name: pick
methods.summary: Returns an array having only keys present in the given path list.
methods.description:
Values for missing keys values will be filled with provided default value.

Usage

__::pick(

    [

        'a' => 1,

        'b' => ['c' => 3, 'd' => 4]

    ],

    ['a', 'b.d']

);

Result

[

    'a' => 1,

    'b' => ['d' => 4]

]

arguments.name: default
arguments.description: The default value that will be used if the specified path does not exist.

methods.name: pluck
methods.summary: Returns an array of values belonging to a given property of each item in a collection.
methods.description:
Usage

$a = [

    ['foo' => 'bar',  'bis' => 'ter' ],

    ['foo' => 'bar2', 'bis' => 'ter2'],

];



__::pluck($a, 'foo');

Result

['bar', 'bar2']

arguments.name: collection
arguments.description: Array or object that can be converted to array

methods.name: reduce
methods.summary: Reduces $collection to a value which is the $accumulator result of running each element in $collection thru $iteratee, where each successive invocation is supplied the return value of the previous.
methods.description:
If $accumulator is not given, the first element of $collection is used as the initial value.

Usage: Sum Example

__::reduce([1, 2], function ($accumulator, $value, $key, $collection) {

    return $accumulator + $value;

}, 0);

Result

3

Usage: Array Counter

$a = [

    ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Indianapolis', 'object' => 'School bus'],

    ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Indianapolis', 'object' => 'Manhole'],

    ['state' => 'IN', 'city' => 'Plainfield', 'object' => 'Basketball'],

    ['state' => 'CA', 'city' => 'San Diego', 'object' => 'Light bulb'],

    ['state' => 'CA', 'city' => 'Mountain View', 'object' => 'Space pen'],

];



$iteratee = function ($accumulator, $value) {

    if (isset($accumulator[$value['city']]))

        $accumulator[$value['city']]++;

    else

        $accumulator[$value['city']] = 1;

    return $accumulator;

};



__::reduce($c, $iteratee, []);

Result

[

   'Indianapolis' => 2,

   'Plainfield' => 1,

   'San Diego' => 1,

   'Mountain View' => 1,

]

Usage: Objects

$object = new \stdClass();

$object->a = 1;

$object->b = 2;

$object->c = 1;



__::reduce($object, function ($result, $value, $key) {

    if (!isset($result[$value]))

        $result[$value] = [];



    $result[$value][] = $key;



    return $result;

}, [])

Result

[

    '1' => ['a', 'c'],

    '2' => ['b']

]

methods.name: reduceRight
methods.summary: Reduces $collection to a value which is the $accumulator result of running each element in $collection - from right to left - thru $iteratee, where each successive invocation is supplied the return value of the previous.
methods.description:
If $accumulator is not given, the first element of $collection is used as the initial value.

Usage

__::reduceRight(['a', 'b', 'c'], function ($accumulator, $value, $key, $collection) {

    return $accumulator . $value;

}, '');

Result

'cba'

methods.name: reverseIterable
methods.summary: Return the reverse of an array or other foreach-able (Iterable).
methods.description:
For array it does not make a copy of it; but does make a copy to memory for other traversables.

Code (using yield) is from mpen and linepogl See https://stackoverflow.com/a/36605605/1956471

Usage

__::reverseIterable([1, 2, 3]);

Result

Generator([3, 2, 1])

methods.name: set
methods.summary: Return a new collection with the item set at index to given value. Index can be a path of nested indexes.
methods.description:
• If $collection is an object that implements the ArrayAccess interface, this function will treat it as an array.
  • If a portion of path doesn't exist, it's created. Arrays are created for missing index in an array; objects are created for missing property in an object.

This function throws an \Exception if the path consists of a non-collection.

Usage

__::set(['foo' => ['bar' => 'ter']], 'foo.baz.ber', 'fer');

Result

['foo' => ['bar' => 'ter', 'baz' => ['ber' => 'fer']]]

arguments.name: path
arguments.description: Key or index. Supports dot notation

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: The value to set at position $key

exceptions.message: if the path consists of a non collection

return.description: the new collection with the item set

methods.name: size
methods.summary: Get the size of an array or \Countable object. Or get the number of properties an object has.
methods.description:
Usage

__::size(null)                    // false

__::size("true")                  // false; a string is not a collection

__::size([1, 2, 3])               // 3

__::size((object)[1, 2])          // 2

__::size(new ArrayIterator(5, 4)) // 2

return.description: False when the given object does not support getting its size.

methods.name: unease
methods.summary: Builds a multidimensional collection out of a hash map using the key as indicator where to put the value.
methods.description:
Usage

__::unease(['foo.bar' => 'ter', 'baz.0' => 'b', , 'baz.1' => 'z']);

Result

['foo' => ['bar' => 'ter'], 'baz' => ['b', 'z']]

arguments.name: separator
arguments.description: The glue used in the keys

methods.name: where
methods.summary: Return data matching specific key value condition.
methods.description:
Usage

$a = [

    ['name' => 'fred',   'age' => 32],

    ['name' => 'maciej', 'age' => 16]

];



__::where($a, ['age' => 16]);

Result

[['name' => 'maciej', 'age' => 16]]

methods.name: slug
methods.summary: Create a web friendly URL slug from a string.
methods.description:
Although supported, transliteration is discouraged because:

  1. most web browsers support UTF-8 characters in URLs
  2. transliteration causes a loss of information

Usage

__::slug('Jakieś zdanie z dużą ilością obcych znaków!');

Result

'jakies-zdanie-z-duza-iloscia-obcych-znakow'

arguments.name: options
arguments.description: method options which includes: delimiter, limit, lowercase, replacements, transliterate

methods.name: truncate
methods.summary: Truncate string based on count of words
methods.description:
Usage

$string = 'Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Pellentesque et mi orci.';



__::truncate($string);

Result

'Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, ...'

methods.name: urlify
methods.summary: Convert any URLs into HTML anchor tags in a string.
methods.description:
Usage

__::urlify("I love https://google.com");

Result

'I love <a href="https://google.com">google.com</a>'

methods.name: isArray
methods.summary: Check if give value is array or not.

methods.name: isCollection
methods.summary: Check if the object is a collection.
methods.description: A collection is either an array or an object.

methods.name: isEmail
methods.summary: Check if the value is valid email.

methods.name: isEqual
methods.summary: Check if the objects are equals.
methods.description:
Perform a deep (recursive) comparison when the parameters are arrays or objects.

Note: This method supports comparing arrays, object objects, booleans, numbers, strings. object objects are compared by their own enumerable properties (as returned by get_object_vars).

Usage

__::isEqual(['honfleur' => 1, 'rungis' => [2, 3]], ['honfleur' => 1, 'rungis' => [1, 2]]);

Result

false

methods.name: isFunction
methods.summary: Check if give value is function or not.

methods.name: isIterable
methods.summary: Check to see if something is iterable.

arguments.name: strict
arguments.description: Match PHP 7.1 behavior where and `\stdClass` is not iterable

methods.name: isNull
methods.summary: Check if give value is null or not.

methods.name: isNumber
methods.summary: Check if give value is number or not.

methods.name: isObject
methods.summary: Check if give value is object or not.

methods.name: isString
methods.summary: Check if give value is string or not.

methods.name: chain
methods.summary: Returns a wrapper instance, allows the value to be passed through multiple bottomline functions.
methods.description:
Usage

__::chain([0, 1, 2, 3, null])

    ->compact()

    ->prepend(4)

    ->value()

;

Result

[4, 1, 2, 3]

methods.name: camelCase
methods.summary: Converts string to camel case.
methods.description:
Usage

__::camelCase('Foo Bar');

Result

'fooBar'

methods.name: capitalize
methods.summary: Converts the first character of string to upper case and the remaining to lower case.
methods.description:
Usage

__::capitalize('FRED');

Result

'Fred'

methods.name: kebabCase
methods.summary: Converts string to kebab case.
methods.description:
Usage

__::kebabCase('Foo Bar');

Result

'foo-bar'

methods.name: lowerCase
methods.summary: Converts string, as space separated words, to lower case.
methods.description:
Usage

__::lowerCase('--Foo-Bar--');

Result

'foo bar'

methods.name: lowerFirst
methods.summary: Converts the first character of string to lower case, like lcfirst.
methods.description:
Usage

__::lowerFirst('Fred');

Result

'fred'

methods.name: snakeCase
methods.summary: Converts string to snake case.
methods.description:
Usage

__::snakeCase('Foo Bar');

Result

'foo_bar'

methods.name: split
methods.summary: Split a string by string.
methods.description:
• If limit is set and positive, the returned array will contain a maximum of limit elements with the last element containing the rest of string.
  • If the limit parameter is negative, all components except the last -limit are returned.
  • If the limit parameter is zero, then this is treated as 1.

Usage

__::split('a-b-c', '-', 2);

Result

['a', 'b-c']

methods.name: startCase
methods.summary: Converts string to start case.
methods.description:
Usage

__::startCase('--foo-bar--');

Result

'Foo Bar'

methods.name: toLower
methods.summary: Converts string, as a whole, to lower case just like strtolower().
methods.description:
Usage

__::toLower('fooBar');

Result

'foobar'

methods.name: toUpper
methods.summary: Converts string, as a whole, to lower case just like strtoupper().
methods.description:
Usage

__::toUpper('fooBar');

Result

'FOOBAR'

methods.name: upperCase
methods.summary: Converts string, as space separated words, to upper case.
methods.description:
Usage

__::upperCase('--foo-bar');

Result

'FOO BAR'

methods.name: upperFirst
methods.summary: Converts the first character of string to upper case, like ucfirst().
methods.description:
Usage

__::upperFirst('fred');

Result

'Fred'

methods.name: words
methods.summary: Splits string into an array of its words.
methods.description:
Usage: Default Behavior

__::words('fred, barney, & pebbles');

Result

['fred', 'barney', 'pebbles']

Use a custom regex to define how words are split.

Usage: Custom Pattern

__::words('fred, barney, & pebbles', '/[^, ]+/');

Result

['fred', 'barney', '&', 'pebbles']

arguments.name: input
arguments.description: The string of words to split.
